definition: lasting for a very short time
example: The ephemeral beauty of cherry blossoms draws millions of visitors each spring.

definition: present, appearing, or found everywhere
example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

definition: to make something bad or unsatisfactory better
example: The new policies were designed to ameliorate the effects of poverty.

definition: carried out with minimum effort or reflection
example: He gave the report a perfunctory glance before signing off on it.

definition: fond of company; sociable
example: Her gregarious nature made her the life of every party.

definition: reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little
example: The taciturn professor rarely spoke outside of class lectures.

definition: tending to talk a great deal; talkative
example: The loquacious host kept guests entertained with endless stories.

definition: difficult to interpret or understand; mysterious
example: The Mona Lisa's enigmatic smile has puzzled viewers for centuries.

definition: dealing with things sensibly and realistically
example: Her pragmatic approach to problem-solving made her an effective manager.

definition: intended to teach or instruct, often excessively
example: The novel was criticized for its overly didactic tone.

definition: having an obstinately uncooperative attitude
example: The recalcitrant student refused to follow classroom rules.

definition: a person who acts obsequiously toward someone important
example: The CEO surrounded himself with sycophants who never questioned his decisions.

definition: characterized by vulgar or pretentious display
example: His ostentatious wealth was evident in his gold-plated car.

definition: extremely unwilling to spend money or use resources
example: The parsimonious landlord refused to make necessary repairs.

definition: obedient or attentive to an excessive degree
example: The obsequious waiter hovered over our table throughout dinner.

definition: excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters
example: My garrulous neighbor can talk for hours about nothing in particular.

definition: using very few words; concise to the point of seeming rude
example: His laconic reply of 'No' ended the discussion.

definition: having a ready insight into and understanding of things
example: The perspicacious detective noticed details others missed.

definition: vehement or clamorous; expressing feelings loudly
example: The vociferous crowd demanded justice.

definition: having little or no money
example: The impecunious artist could barely afford rent.

definition: given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior
example: The capricious weather made it hard to plan outdoor events.

definition: optimistic or positive, especially in a bad situation
example: Despite the setbacks, she remained sanguine about the project's success.

definition: having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition
example: His phlegmatic response to the crisis surprised everyone.

definition: complaining in a petulant or whining manner
example: The querulous patient constantly found fault with the nurses.

definition: eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant
example: The truculent teenager refused to back down from the argument.

definition: very generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival
example: The winner was magnanimous in victory, praising his opponent's skills.

definition: showing a lack of courage or determination; timid
example: His pusillanimous refusal to stand up for his beliefs disappointed his supporters.

definition: cheerful and full of energy
example: Her ebullient personality made everyone around her feel happy.

definition: looking or sounding sad and dismal
example: The lugubrious music set a somber tone for the memorial.

definition: lacking flavor or interest; dull
example: The insipid conversation made the dinner party drag on.

definition: clear, logical, and convincing
example: The lawyer presented a cogent argument that swayed the jury.

definition: superficially plausible but actually wrong
example: His specious reasoning fooled many people at first.

definition: to regard with great respect; revere
example: Many cultures venerate their elders for their wisdom.

definition: to speak or write about in an abusively disparaging manner
example: The tabloids sought to vilify the celebrity with false accusations.

definition: to show or declare that someone is not guilty of wrongdoing
example: New evidence helped exculpate the wrongly convicted man.

definition: to make guilt or an offense seem less serious
example: Nothing could extenuate the severity of his crime.

definition: to use ambiguous language to conceal the truth
example: The politician continued to equivocate when asked direct questions.

definition: to make obscure, unclear, or unintelligible
example: The lawyer's jargon seemed designed to obfuscate the simple facts.

definition: to spread information widely
example: The internet has made it easier to disseminate news globally.

definition: to cause an event or situation to happen suddenly
example: The scandal precipitated the minister's resignation.

definition: to win or regain the favor of someone by doing something that pleases them
example: He tried to propitiate his angry boss with a heartfelt apology.

definition: to overwhelm someone with things to be dealt with
example: After the announcement, customer service was inundated with calls.

definition: to cause someone to feel drained of energy
example: The hot, humid weather seemed to enervate everyone.

definition: to give strength or energy to
example: The cool morning air invigorated the hikers.

definition: official permission or approval; to impose penalties for disobeying
example: The committee refused to sanction the proposed changes.

definition: directly opposed or contrasted; mutually incompatible
example: His actions were antithetical to his stated beliefs.

definition: showing great care and perseverance
example: Her assiduous study habits led to academic success.

definition: naturally accompanying or associated
example: Stress is a concomitant of high-pressure jobs.

definition: pressing; demanding immediate attention
example: The exigent circumstances required immediate action.

definition: just begun and so not fully formed or developed
example: The inchoate plan needed more development before presentation.

definition: tending to obstruct or harm; unfriendly; hostile
example: Policies inimical to small businesses hurt the local economy.

definition: just beginning to develop
example: The nascent democracy faced many challenges.

definition: translucently clear; easily understood
example: Her pellucid prose made complex ideas accessible.

definition: of or occurring every day; ordinary
example: She longed to escape the quotidian routine of office life.

definition: little known; abstruse
example: The professor's recondite lectures confused most students.

definition: expressing or intending to promote a particular cause or point of view
example: The documentary was criticized for its tendentious portrayal of events.

definition: the appearance of being true or real
example: The author's attention to detail gave the novel verisimilitude.

definition: a person who is fanatically devoted to a cause
example: The political zealot refused to consider opposing viewpoints.

definition: to abolish or annul by authority
example: The new government moved to abrogate the oppressive laws.

definition: feeling or expressing remorse for wrongdoing
example: The contrite defendant apologized sincerely to the victims.

definition: to raise doubts or objections; to show reluctance
example: She demurred at the suggestion that she was to blame.

definition: a feeling of listlessness and dissatisfaction arising from boredom
example: Summer ennui set in after weeks without stimulating activities.

definition: treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor
example: His facetious remarks during the meeting were unwelcome.

definition: relevant to a subject under consideration
example: Please keep your comments germane to the topic at hand.

definition: a lengthy and aggressive speech; to lecture aggressively
example: The coach's harangue motivated the team to play harder.

definition: a person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
example: The artist was known as an iconoclast who challenged traditional art forms.

definition: naive, simplistic, and superficial; lacking interest
example: The critic dismissed the novel as jejune and unoriginal.

definition: to act in an excessively subservient manner
example: He refused to kowtow to unreasonable demands.

definition: subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood
example: Her mercurial temperament made her difficult to work with.

definition: wicked, villainous, or criminal
example: The nefarious scheme was eventually uncovered by investigators.

definition: to remove or prevent a difficulty
example: Proper planning can obviate many potential problems.

definition: excessively concerned with minor details or rules
example: His pedantic insistence on proper grammar annoyed his colleagues.

definition: exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical
example: His quixotic plans to reform the system were doomed to fail.

definition: strongly reminiscent or suggestive of; fragrant
example: The kitchen was redolent of freshly baked bread.

definition: not being what it purports to be; false or fake
example: The spurious claims were quickly debunked by experts.

definition: a feeling of fear or agitation about something
example: She approached the interview with considerable trepidation.

definition: offense or annoyance
example: He took umbrage at the suggestion that he was incompetent.

definition: denoting a fault or offense that is forgivable
example: The venial mistake was quickly forgiven and forgotten.

definition: deliberate and unprovoked; unrestrained
example: The wanton destruction of property shocked the community.

definition: the highest point reached by something
example: Her career reached its zenith when she won the Nobel Prize.

definition: brisk and cheerful readiness
example: She accepted the challenge with alacrity.

definition: demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight
example: The bellicose rhetoric increased tensions between the nations.

definition: distress or embarrassment at having failed
example: To her chagrin, she discovered the mistake after the presentation.

definition: modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence
example: The diffident student rarely spoke up in class.

definition: insolent or impertinent behavior
example: He had the effrontery to demand a raise after his poor performance.

definition: attempting to avoid notice or attention
example: She cast a furtive glance at the clock during the meeting.

definition: sly or cunning intelligence
example: He used guile rather than force to achieve his goals.

definition: excessive pride or self-confidence
example: His hubris led to his downfall when he underestimated his opponents.

definition: unable to be placated or appeased
example: She faced implacable opposition from her rivals.

definition: to place close together for contrasting effect
example: The artist juxtaposed light and dark to create visual tension.

definition: to arouse or inspire an emotion or feeling
example: Her words kindled hope in the hearts of her followers.

definition: completely clear and transparent; easily understood
example: The limpid water revealed the colorful coral below.

definition: very generous
example: The munificent donor funded the entire scholarship program.

definition: a scheme or remedy for bringing about some social or political reform
example: Politicians often propose simple nostrums for complex problems.

definition: ostentatiously rich and luxurious
example: The opulent mansion featured gold fixtures and marble floors.

definition: the presence of something only in small or insufficient quantities
example: The paucity of evidence made it difficult to prosecute the case.

definition: a soft boggy area of land; an awkward or difficult situation
example: The project became a bureaucratic quagmire.

definition: not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily
example: He was reticent about discussing his personal life.

definition: calm, dependable, and showing little emotion
example: The stolid guard remained unmoved by the commotion.

definition: mentally or physically inactive; lethargic
example: The heat made everyone feel torpid and unmotivated.
